context.text: Mr. Solicitor General, before you get to answering Mr. Justice Frankfurter's question, which I'm also anxious to hear you answer, gets the more on the bright side out of the way.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: If you are wrong, the Government is wrong that any or all of this search and seizure cannot be supported on the administrative warrant, are you making any argument as to any of those items and if so, which ones that their admission in face of the fact that you get Hayhanen finally to testify was harmless error?

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Well, we think it -- they were accumulated and the other evidence were so overwhelming that they would not be controlling in the case, but the code book is an important evidence on espionage in identifying Abel with us.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: That would affect whether or not the due process from then on.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: From then on.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: I think --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But -- but wouldn't it shed a light under justification, if you do not treat -- so if you do not treat the seizure as incident to an arrest for which you have probable cause and you do not so treat it because you do not follow the consequences, as Mr. Justice Stewart just suggest, then you can justify it because the conduct negative the justification.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Well, if we had done that, you would say it was a mere subterfuge or device to get the evidence for that purpose instead of for purposes of deportation.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You mean if we have done what?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Either didn't the search and seizure of documents relevant to -- exclusively relevant to deportation, you're saying things that right here has travelled far outside what an administrative warrant or any implied right from search and seizure would have justified.

context.speaker: James B. Donovan
context.text: The simplest way to state my position is that insofar as anyone of these procedures is pertinent to my case which is the conviction of the man for the capital crime of espionage, I challenge it insofar as it's not pertinent to my case and there is no need for me to go beyond it, I'm assuming, I'm arguendo.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The question is whether you challenge it, whether you not challenge it, it maybe very important to whether -- it maybe very important whether or not, being (Inaudible) or whatever reasons you chose not to challenge the legality of arrest for deportation, you just challenged that.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Now, as Justice Harlan said the consequences of that maybe another case, but you can't come here as far as I'm concerned and say you now have a challenge, the warrant for apprehension for deportation, restricted to that legal act on the consequence of that legal act.

context.speaker: James B. Donovan
context.text: Ordinarily -- ordinarily, Your Honor, it's my understanding of the rules of this Court indeed, that the Court doesn't pass on hypothetical questions and I have simply studied this and challenged it and did in the District Court, as I believe this memorandum showed there's no change from my --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I'm suggesting that a missing hypothetical to consider whether it is relevant that if the warrant of arrest or deportation not challenged impliedly in law to authorize and use -- make certain doctrine of -- and it didn't challenge that, that maybe relevant to the consequences of that as far as the criminal prosecution.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: But I -- I think involved in the particular questions the Court has asked us as to whether these questions are properly before the Court, is the question of whether or not the -- the arrest was legal.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: And there are some problems that I think get in a shaded area which he could properly have before this Court and I think they're in the questions that he had before the Court in the other argument.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: But I want to call attention to how explicit they were about this arrest being legal as they viewed it, so that the -- the trial court tried to find out that very thing on page 19 of the Government's supplemental brief.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Solicitor General, before you get to that, you -- you stated the issue in response to Mr. Justice Frankfurter's question.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now, does that include the -- the right to the search that was made here on the basis of the administrative warrant?

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Well, Mr. Chief Justice, I think that the first you -- despite what counsel says you have to comport (Inaudible).

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: That is your position?

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: And I want --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: That is part of this issue as you have -- have stated it in response to Mr. Frankfurter's question -- Mr. Justice Frankfurter's (Inaudible) --

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Maybe he can't get to the suitcase as fast as we can and we don't have to -- we can't touch that and the other things.”

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: So, it seems to me, its quite different when you pick up these things to move it and by the very nature, they have to be picked up pretty much his items and put in the suitcase to see whether there's any instruments of criminality or contraband in connection with him, than if you're going around and pulling suit files or if he wasn't going to move from there, if they've gone through all the covers and search his things and handled in that matter.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Now, that's what --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If I understand you to answer Justice Harlan a little earlier that all the four items, the other four items, were -- were tied to or related to or relevant to his deportability?

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Yes, Mr. Justice.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Now --

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: We had a prima facie case and that's the requirement of the Immigration Act and as the regulations and instructions provide and we had it in this case and this Court has said a prima facie case is more than probable cause because the prima facie case, if not rebutted, establishes the case and probable cause is merely what a reasonable person would have probable cause to believe that crime was committed.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You're talking about the prima facie case for deportation?

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In answer to a question of Justice Harlan's before lunch, you reminded us that the failure to advice the -- was it the Secretary of State or Attorney -- Attorney General or at least his presence, is not only subjects him to deportation but also a misdemeanor –

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: Yes Mr. Justice --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: -- under the statute, under the criminal statute?

context.speaker: Charles S. Friedman
context.text: -- Your Honor, we're -- we're somewhat puzzled as to what the Court of Appeals are trying to say.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: It's unlikely.

context.speaker: Charles S. Friedman
context.text: And I think the Court of Appeals is somewhat puzzled and we're -- we're more convinced to that in reading two subsequent decisions of theirs in which they have circumvented this very -- this very question.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, it has what Mr. Justice Frankfurter suggested (Inaudible) what they are opposing from is -- it's not the New York statute, possibly (Inaudible) Section 3670 of the United States Code.

context.speaker: Charles S. Friedman
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Charles S. Friedman
context.text: They're trying to define --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Things have happened that are unconceivable in this world.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Is that true?

context.speaker: Samuel D. Slade
context.text: Yes, I think so.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: So that -- so that when you replied to Justice Black a little while ago, he abandoned or what was the word?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: He (Inaudible) he abandoned his lien.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Didn't you -- he had a lien and lost it.

context.speaker: Samuel D. Slade
context.text: We had to pay a lot more than that to get the boats finished and now, we're being asked to pay these or any other people who dealt with Rice, subsequent to the time we executed the contract and whom Rice didn't pay.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Do you think --

context.speaker: Samuel D. Slade
context.text: Who's ever paid or not?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Do you think that the situation had been as Justice Black outlined a situation that the Court of Claims, under its theory in this case, would have decided differently?

context.text: My recollection is the brief does not put an issue of these facts.

context.text: I do think it's important to -- in regard to literacy as the Court did in the Lastner case to keep in mind that if your literacy test is one that obviously is going to discriminate --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That's what I do solely, yes.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: -- on the basis of raise or color, then it's one that can't stand up against the --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And what you answered a little while ago, I think to Justice Whittaker, if the same test of a -- of a failure to live up or a very fastidious standard would throw out the 10% of whites and 50% of Negroes, you also got a different problem there.

context.speaker: J. Lee Rankin
context.text: It's very --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I was thinking of -- of the intrinsic invalidity of a very high in my point of view, even exquisite standard of literacy or intelligence.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You may not.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: After they've been put off the rolls which is indispensable to the exercise to the franchise.

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And as Justice Black has indicated, the -- the findings of facts are that they are off the roll because they were taken off and they were taken off because of they were colored.

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: I do not agree with the statement but --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: No, isn't that Judge Wright found?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Yes and the -- and the -- they didn't respond to the challenges issued because from their point of view, a colored man who did this doesn't -- doesn't qualify whereas a white man does and that's what I call discrimination if it's true.

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: I think that it's not true if it please the Court --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, then you are really addressing yourself.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: You don't stop as Justice Black started in this question, namely there were findings of the facts that they were taken off the rolls, because they were colored people although the reason given was, that they didn't spell the name right or put an extra I or didn't cross the thing, but you say that you don't accept those findings as the starting point for legal discussion.

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: That's correct, I do not.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well.

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: 244, I think it's a kind of challenge.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: All right, now, let's go to 245 --

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: -- if it please the Court.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: -- which is Mr. Justice Black situation where the man is presented the affidavit, two affidavits have been presented against him, saying he misspelled the word -- the word Louisiana, he has 10 days within which to rejoin, doesn't he?

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: He comes in but he cannot correct the misspelling of Louisiana in the original registration challenge.

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: He comes in but he cannot correct the misspelling of Louisiana in the original registration challenge.

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: Now then, answering Mr. Justice Black's question quite specifically has the Registrar any power to leave him on the roll or must he strike him off?

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: I thought I answer that before by saying he has the power to leave on the rolls.

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: However again, the challenger has the power to take him into Court and let the Court determine whether or not this applicant has met the standards.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I thought I understood you but you said, if he's performing his duty he must accept that challenge as sustained.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Did I misunderstand?

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: Your Honor, of course, you're placing me in the position here of trying to determine what each Registrar around the State of Louisiana would do --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: No, I'm asking you what your conception is under the law of the duty of the Registrar not whether he wants to wink an eye but -- but does he under the law may do what Judge -- Justice Black suggested?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The fellow has made eight misspellings but the Registrar knows him, he make a good citizen and he's an honorable man and all the rest, has he -- that much leeway to decide whether it comes within the statute.

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: Your Honor here has no more leeway than the courts would allow him if he allowed this --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Now, take the -- take the exhibit if the Government (Inaudible) his brief on page -- open at page 42.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Mr. Cousins and if does A do not computed correctly on application, age do not considered correctly on application, well that's a -- that's an arithmetic calculation, isn't it?

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Now, and so, no affidavit as Justice Whittaker suggested could -- could change that correct challenge if that would be a correct challenge, could it?

context.speaker: Weldon A. Cousins
context.text: I would say that it is conceivable that it could, if it please Justice Frankfurter for the --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But just as you give (Inaudible) would you?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Was any such offer made?

context.speaker: Henry J. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: No offer was made to my knowledge of that, sir.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. -- Mr. Roberts, may I ask you this question?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. -- Mr. Justice Black was trying to get an answer to it yesterday, I thought, and it's this.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Are you -- are you saying to us now that there was not sufficient evidence to support the findings of Judge Wright or -- are you saying to us that the findings of Judge Wright are not sufficient to support the position of the Government?

context.speaker: Henry J. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: That's -- what I am trying to say, sir, is that the findings of Judge Wright were on the fact that he ignored in my opinion, the basic requirement of the Louisiana law which indicates that you must pass the test for illiteracy.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I understand --

context.speaker: Henry J. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: -- only the State of Louisiana.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I understand that's your contention, if it's a bona fide effort -- if it's a bona fide law, if you're stating bona fide, saying, the States.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: But if it's a mere -- as we tell that Justice Frankfurter calls your attention, would that make any difference how ingenious it may be if the purpose in the end works out to exclude people on account of their color.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: As you know, there was --

context.speaker: Henry J. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Elliot Bredhoff
context.text: Justice Frankfurter, the extrinsic evidence, mind you, would be submitted to the arbitrator.

context.speaker: Elliot Bredhoff
context.text: And that --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But you said here, that -- that the $3, a provision that the rate shall be $3 an hour maybe supplemented or extended by what Justice Stewart called common law understanding or an explicit understanding between the parties deal or with written document.

context.speaker: Elliot Bredhoff
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Why is -- why is $3, they made -- may be made to mean $3.50 by extrinsic oral testimony.

context.speaker: Elliot Bredhoff
context.text: -- provisions on the merit.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: But --

context.speaker: Elliot Bredhoff
context.text: Now --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- but there's a -- there's a -- an emphasis of what Justice Harlan just said.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If you will add that if you claim, not that it's an extension or an addition to or a modification of the arbitration clause but comes within it.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That is not subject to court scrutiny.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: So the --

context.speaker: William C. Beatty
context.text: And it comes down to what we argue.

context.speaker: William C. Beatty
context.text: We say that it's a question here as to whether or not this was within the scope of authority.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Except that as Justice Harlan is suggesting.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The real question is whether he may determine that over the Court has to determine.

context.speaker: William C. Beatty
context.text: Of course, we say that the Court must determine it.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: I would like very briefly to reply to my friend, the Solicitor General.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart, you asked the question of where we got our 1% figure from.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: If you'll look at page 92 of the record, you will find that the source is the Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization of the United States Government.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: It's less by quarters, starting first quarter of 1958, the amount of shipments of steel products for all defense purposes, it is less than 1% over the last year.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: If you'll look at page 92 of the record, you will find that the source is the Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization of the United States Government.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: It's less by quarters, starting first quarter of 1958, the amount of shipments of steel products for all defense purposes, it is less than 1% over the last year.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And I think that's an appendix statement of the Government's need in the defense they're at.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Mr. Justice Black, you inquired as to legislative history on health and safety.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: There is some illumination in this area that we haven't adverted to.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Senator Smith was a distinguished man or member of the Senate Labor Committee, later it became the ranking republican member.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: In other words, we would require a specification.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: They have to prove their case that this is something that causes a peril to the national health.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Now, while they talk about national health, let me say this.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: I've been struggling since the questions were asked this morning, Mr. Justice Harlan, your question, what about this term “national”?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And I should have known better because I argue the case which involved that question in this Court.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The amalgamated streetcar case, where there was a health problem involving a local utility, and it was a gas utility.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Well, I assume that one of the aspects of national is the thing that is involved in coal and railroad transportation that must pertain to the nation at large.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: But not in steel?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Not in steel because they have not shown of the Government evidence that this involves the nation at large.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Now, Mr. Justice Brennan, this morning, you asked me if the Government made a case on safety but not health, would that be enough of the case.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And I said yes.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: I -- I ment -- I should have put a copy which I am sure was in fight from my prior argument that this is so, if my other elements were not proved like part of the industry and -- and discretion and so.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: It never was our position in any court.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The record shows, Record 92.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: My statement to the District Court, Record 153, that it was theory that if the plant had to be reopened then it would be reopened for all purposes.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Mr. Justice Frankfurter, I worry more about you're question to me about jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And maybe I have a better answer now that I gave them before (Inaudible) assistant.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And that is that where you read the language on jurisdiction in -- if I may refer to in page 95 of the appendix to the Government brief Section 208 (a) 2 permitted to occur to continue will imperil the national, health or safety, it shall have jurisdiction to enjoin any such strike or lockout or the continuing thereof and to make such other ordinance.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, that -- the statute has imperiled the national health or safety.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: In the -- you're correct Mr. Justice Brennan I stand corrected.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And here's we have an opinion that it does both here and if that is -- that is correct.

context.speaker: Charles E. Whittaker
context.text: And in view of the fact that the President could not make a finding in this matter as distinguished from the opinions and the question anyway with the statute.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: We argued today on Tuesday, November the 3rd.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: This is exactly two weeks.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The case has proceeded on final hearing, two, three courts to, through two courts and now in the Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And Mr. Justice Harlan, you asked about an objection, whether I objected to this, and I will say at this point and later I want to explain the nature of my comments, not an objection, that while justice delayed is justice denied, I will raise the question later as to whether under the procedures specified in the statute and with no criticism of the courts below.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And in fact, commendation for their expedition, whether the procedure necessarily entailed in the statute is compatible with the judicial process.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And then I would like to comment on at a later stage of the argument.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Where they -- where they talk about unemployment, where they talk about the number of people unemployed.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: I shall deal with that in my discussion of economic health.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Now on the second theory of the Government adopted by the District Court, is that national safety will be imperiled because the shortage of certain steel affects the progress of certain defense activities.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: This is the finding Mr. Justice Brennan that you just adverted to.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Now in my opinion, and upon the congressional history and a plain meaning of the Act, each determination is based upon a serious misreading of the statute.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: First, economic health is not relevant to health in the statutory sentence.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: One was passed in the House and one was passed in the Senate.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The House bill referred to national health or safety or interest, three words, health, safety, or interest.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: That was public health though, wasn't it?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And at times there were discussions of public health and even in this statute, we'll talk about the statement of purposes in just a moment, Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: There was some reference to public hereto.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Does it -- could that -- to see if I an understanding your position.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: There is a fundamentally wrong thing with that and perhaps two.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: One is, I would have assumed that Debs was discredited even with the Government?

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Why do you say that when Mr. Justice Brandeis cited it in the unanimous opinion not so long ago?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Well, I say that because of the -- what I thought was the march of events, Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Maybe I'm wrong.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I'm suggesting that it was best in use by this Court when Mr. Justice Brandeis, who knew something about labor and we're not unfriendly to it, in the opinion.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Well, I say that because of the -- what I thought was the march of events, Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Maybe I'm wrong.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I'm suggesting that it was best in use by this Court when Mr. Justice Brandeis, who knew something about labor and we're not unfriendly to it, in the opinion.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: But, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, the way it was used was within the limits of the facts of Debs.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well that's a different story but it's of the case to discredit it.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Well I --

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: This publication demonstrates that 20 of the 23 companies making this particular type of steel are not on strike, 20 of the 23.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Just as a matter of information, is there anything in the record by which we can tell what defense orders, if that's the correct term to use, what defense orders are actually in place at those non-struck plants or what percent of the orders placed by the Government elsewhere are dependent upon steel from those non-struck plants?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: There's nothing in the record.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: I was just saying, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, we attempted to find out without success, although -- although I must say this, and this illustrates this corporate secrecy that's put on this.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The Metal Magazine which is an industry magazine illuminates us very largely on this subject.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: It goes into a great detail; it doesn't tell us purportedly, but it goes into great detail of these things, telling that the constituency, the type of steel, the place, the project for which it is designed or when the union desiring to cooperate with its Government request the information, this information is denied to the union.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: There was nothing.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And then -- and there are no -- there are no affidavits where security considerations are involved.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: But later on, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, I'm going to talk to that subject on -- on evidence.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Now I say that where the record does show without contradiction that a minute amount of steel is required, particularly specialty steel, a minute part, Government can make no claim that carbon steel is not available, because this 22 million tons is -- is in large part carbon steel whereupon specialty steel, all the Government requires of specialty steel, is required --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Would you mind telling -- telling me at least what specialty steel is?

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Congress has acted in this area not by injunction, but just a fatal fallacy of the Government's case.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Congress has at least three statutes which bear on this subject.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: One is the Selective Service Act of 1948 as Your Honors had occasion to consider in the Steel Seizure case in 1952.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Now in the several opinions of the Steel Seizure case, Mr. Justice Clark, you talked about it at some length.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Mr. Justice Jackson talked about it.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The Selective Service Act says specifically that if there is a commodity and it refers specifically to steel at one stage, necessary for the defense of our country, and if the employer refuses or fails to produce it, then the Government may seize that instrumentality.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Congress has at least three statutes which bear on this subject.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: One is the Selective Service Act of 1948 as Your Honors had occasion to consider in the Steel Seizure case in 1952.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Now in the several opinions of the Steel Seizure case, Mr. Justice Clark, you talked about it at some length.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Mr. Justice Jackson talked about it.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The Selective Service Act says specifically that if there is a commodity and it refers specifically to steel at one stage, necessary for the defense of our country, and if the employer refuses or fails to produce it, then the Government may seize that instrumentality.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And that's a statutory seizure.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Now on that record, I believe that the Government has not sustained its burden.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And again I emphasize the burden, the case was tried, on final trial, this was not a preliminary order.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The burden is on the Government to prove by clear and preponderating evidence that national health or safety was involved.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And on the safety factor, we have, let's get back Mr. Justice Frankfurter, to the affidavit.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: We have scanned the affidavit for the Government.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: It is truly tried within affidavits.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And for health purposes for that matter, that health could be sustained.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Now I turn again to the statute.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It's your point -- you're not referring to a fraction of a plant, are you?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Well, although I'm not at the mood but it could be done in the steel, Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Steel plants if I may explain it are -- are of varying types.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: The -- you have integrated plants you have non integrated plants.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: -- as to his forecast which deserve a great deal of respect.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: What I'm suggesting with some knowledge of settling strikes and big strikes but that's a very speculative judgment that anybody can make.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And -- and Mr. Justice Frankfurter, we have a settlement two days after this.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: A settlement.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Yes, but a substantial one.

United Steelworkers of America v. United.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Steelworkers of America v. United.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. United States
United Steelworkers of America v. United.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 1959 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: But frankly as I read Judge Brandeis's decision in that, Mr. Justice Brandeis's decision in that case, I come to the conclusion in my own mind that that case is a sport, derived from the fact that this function has been performed by the federal courts in 1795.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And when you have a case of that character, special in character, I don't think that that case ought to be extended to open the federal courts to functions which the federal courts should not, under the Constitution, perform.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And I -- this leads me to a final observation of the statute.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And this has to do with matter that Mr. Justice Frankfurter you queried me about and said I would cover in detail later.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: What is the judicial function involved in making the determinations which has to be made in this case if an injunction is to issue?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And on this record these are the determinations which a court of equity is required to make.

United Steelworkers of America v. Warrio.speaker: Justice Frankfurter

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But the way, as I understand your position then, the evidence dealing with contracting out was submitted and relied upon here.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: It was not offered for that limited purpose of the interpretation in the arbitration clause.

context.speaker: David E. Feller
context.text: Well, at least, it was not made the findings which I'd direct Your Honor's attention to which appear at particularly on page 105 on the record.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Justice Brennan's question would arise more -- more concretely if the grievance to which you call our attention on page 104 had been explicitly opened to be inserted in the agreement and reject it.

context.speaker: David E. Feller
context.text: In the arbitration clause, we've said that all questions of contracting out --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: No.

United Steelworkers of America v. Warrio.speaker: Justice Frankfurter
United Steelworkers of America v. Warrio.case_name: United Steelworkers of America v. Warrior & Gulf Navigation Company
United Steelworkers of America v. Warrio.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 27, 1960

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And all talk about intention let's loose a lot of hairs.

context.speaker: David E. Feller
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: David E. Feller
context.text: And --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: And I think also you ought to have been, what shall I say, should have agreed to a considerable extent to adjust the import of Justice Whittaker's question as to how much under your claim is necessarily left to the arbitrator not to determine his jurisdiction, that's another mischievous word in this connection, but how much of the wording of the system is dependent upon the arbitral skilled worker.

context.speaker: David E. Feller
context.text: Oh, I -- I've misunderstood the question if -- if you thought I must answer.

context.speaker: David E. Feller
context.text: I have no doubt, this I would state as an article of faith on the question of the whole process as because I participated in the process.

context.speaker: Samuel Lang
context.text: Well, in this case, sir, he supports us almost right down to the last teeth.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: (Inaudible) supports --

context.speaker: Samuel Lang
context.text: [Laughs]

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: -- you with, Justice Frankfurter had him on one opinion, I had him on another.

context.speaker: Samuel Lang
context.text: But this Court and Professor Cox both have said on occasion that the mere fact that this is a labor agreement, which we're interpreting here, doesn't mean that we have to abandon all the principles which we have followed in all these years in the interpretation of labor agreements.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I hope we can all agree on that.

context.speaker: J. Alston Atkins
context.text: That's -- I would like --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: May I ask you a question Mr. --

context.speaker: J. Alston Atkins
context.text: Mr. Justice Frankfurter, I would like to --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: (Inaudible) on the question out to you by Mr. Justice Stewart, you would be good enough to turn to page on 105 of the record?

context.speaker: J. Alston Atkins
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: The (Inaudible) is tended by the defendant, (Inaudible) Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I'm not --

context.speaker: Roger G. Connor
context.text: -- commerce and vice --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: I'm not denying that, I looked through the period of its passage, and no doubt Congress may utilize the Commerce Clause where it's consequential denied and benevolent and desirable purposes.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: All I'm saying is that when you come to invoke the rule of victim, you're making an assumption which doesn't apply -- which you reject in the case put by Mr. Justice Black.

context.speaker: Roger G. Connor
context.text: No Your Honor.

context.speaker: Seymour B. Goldman
context.text: I am --

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: If I -- I sought the United States Marshall in New York, I made it in the Committee two legally set legally responsible and punishable consequences, namely, assault ordinary assault and interfering with the -- with the business of the court.

context.speaker: Seymour B. Goldman
context.text: That would have been -- I -- I believe that defined in two separate actions or separate sections of the statute.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: Well, that's where the exchange we have with Justice Brennan, and it makes all the difference in the world, they're not separated in a single paragraph as a matter of English by semicolons or commas but they're separated by having A, B, C or one, two, three.

context.speaker: Seymour B. Goldman
context.text: I believe that that is correct.

context.speaker: Felix Frankfurter
context.text: That shouldn't -- that's your position.
